text:
While upgrading my old Tomcat 3.x to 4 b7, I noticed, new version does not 
recognize zipped file under web-inf/lib !! I tried renaming it to .jar and it 
worked. Just thought it might be a BUG or is it new thing in version 4?

Regards.
Jitendra
creator: jayceeamm@yahoo.com

text:
Only JAR files will be added to the classloader repositories in Tomcat 4.x, as 
mandated by the servlet API. This is not a new thing or a bug in Tomcat 4, it's 
just that this behavior, which was proprietary to Tomcat 3.x, has been removed 
(err, never added, actually) in Tomcat 4.0.
creator: remm@apache.org
georg-schmid@ti.com
text:
The problem is that several companies (a number of them being really 
unimportant, like Oracle) provide their JDBC drivers in .zip files, not .jar 
files. It's a nuisance to have to rename all the classes12.zip files to 
classes12.jar files just because Tomcat 4.x is stubborn in this respect.

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
Servlet Specification 2.3, Section 9.5, clearly identifies *only* JAR files as 
being picked up by servlet containers.  Making Tomcat break the spec (and be 
non-portable in that respect) is not a good solution to an application vendor 
who ignores the standard conventions.

creator: francis.andre@easynet.fr
text:
Hello


Just a small remark:

From a coherence point of view, or more precisely an uncoherence view,IMHO, it 
seems strange to me that the Servlet Specification allows to have an "welcome 
file" be either index.html or index.htm while allowing only the "jar" suffix in 
the WEB-INF/lib directory.

What 's matter is more the content than the file's extension even if the suffix 
is commonly driving the kind of process applyied to a file. So why not 
accepting file structured as a "JAR" but suffixed by whatever reasonable 
extension like .jar, .zip, .obf, or even .sig for a signed jar.

Regards
